basics.name: Andreas Biberacher
basics.label: Problem Solver || Software Modernization | Data Engineering | Cloud Computing | Cybersecurity & Risk Management | Agile Leadership (改善) ||
basics.summary:
I'm a passionate Tech Lead with broad knowledge in Cloud Computing, Data Engineering, Cybersecurity, and Legacy Modernization. With a strong focus on delivering reliable and value-centric solutions, I thrive in an environment where quality and continuous improvement are paramount.

I embody a hands-on mentality, leading by example to inspire and motivate my team. My experience in team development enables me to guide cross-functional groups towards success, fostering collaboration, and delivering reliable results.

I have a deep understanding of Cloud Computing, leveraging its vast potential to architect secure and scalable systems. I stay at the forefront of emerging technologies and industry trends, proactively identifying and mitigating potential cybersecurity risks to safeguard critical data assets.

Beyond my technical expertise, I am dedicated to social engagement and giving back to the community. I actively contribute to open-source projects and love to share knowledge (tech talks, mentoring, lectureships at universities), as well as collaborating with like-minded professionals to drive innovation and foster collective growth.

Here are some key highlights of my background:

• Proven track record as a Tech Lead, successfully delivering complex projects and business objectives.
• Extensive experience in cloud-based solutions, especially in designing and executing multi-cloud and edge-computing strategies with Kubernetes.
• Deep knowledge of cybersecurity principles, implementing robust measures during the software development process and in the cloud to protect sensitive information.
• Proficient in data engineering, utilizing distributed data processing (Apache Spark, Kafka) to extract valuable insights and drive informed decision-making.
• Specialized in the topic of application modernization from COBOL/Mainframe to Java/Cloud.
• Audience-centered communication skills to include stakeholders (developers, business experts, C-level, and external customers) in decision-making processes.
• A leader, fostering a culture of innovation, collaboration, and growth within cross-functional teams.

To sum it up, I am the bridge between management, stakeholders, and the engine room. With my in-depth technical and leadership expertise, I navigate through the complexity of a VUCA-driven landscape, constantly maintaining an overview. By building and involving cross-functional teams, I turn my knowledge into reliable and value-creating solutions, starting from day one.

Let's connect and explore ways we can Let's connect and explore ways we can prosper together.

work.name: T-Systems on site services GmbH
work.summary:
Scope: Elaboration of an interface modernization and standardization strategy for a mainframe-based, mission-critical product data system of a large automotive company.
Sector: Automotive

Main Responsibilities:
• Assessment of existing mainframe based system interfaces and middleware components
• Re-architecting of high demand system modules by decoupling interfaces from the application core
• Standardizing interfaces based on the technologies REST and Apache Kafka
• Designing an event-based data streaming process for business objects to a centralized Data Mesh via Apache Spark
• Representation of company interests in customer architecture boards
• Project management and team coordination (local, nearshore, and offshore)

Tech Stack: Java, Spring, Kubernetes, Azure, AWS, REST, Apache Kafka, Apache Spark, Mainframe, WebSphere, COBOL, SOAP, CICS, SFTP, IBM MQ, IMS, DB2,  Apache Cassandra, PostgreSQL, arc42, risk management, threat modelling, DevSecOps

work.name: QUANTO Solutions
work.summary:
Title: IT security in microservice-based systems - From monolith to a secure cloud-native application

Key findings:
• Microservices have a broader attack surface compared to monolithic architectures. On the other hand, they offer new potentials to achieve high availability and attack mitigation by a defense-in-depth approach instead of pure perimeter defense.
• The API-Gateway and Service Registry are critical components in a microservice architecture and must be protected against specific (e.g., service spoofing, DNS/config poisoning, feigned health status), as well as generic (OWASP Top10, DDoS, MITM) attacks.
• Security audits using NIST CSF and ISO/IEC 27001 help identify and prioritize risks and address them through measures like circuit breakers, single-service-per-host policies, and container isolation.

Tech Stack: Java, Java EE, Spring, Docker, Cloud Foundry (SAP), AWS, MS Azure, Openshift, Jenkins

work.name: Capgemini
work.summary:
Title: Industry 4.0 predictive quality analysis in industrial manufacturing - analysis and visualization of data streams.

Key findings:
• Predictive quality analysis in sensor production can lead to a reduction in production costs of between 15-30% depending on the manufacturing depth. 
• The best analytical results came from decaying windows in combination with streaming k-NN (supervised) or streaming k-Means (unsupervised) learning algorithms. McDiarmid decision trees can be an alternative, if sufficient computing resources are available and resistance to noise is required.
• As a reference architecture for distributed k-Means real-time analyses, Apache Spark with Hadoop is a suitable choice.

Tech Stack: Business case analysis, Hadoop, Spark, Python, PyTorch, AWS, Tableau

references.name: Jovita Kanza
references.reference:
While at Groundbreaker, I had the incredible opportunity to be mentored by Andreas Biberacher. From the very beginning, our conversations were more than just about software engineering, they were about growth, problem-solving, and seeing things from new perspectives. Through this mentorship, I was able to openly share my ideas, and Andreas always provided insightful feedback, helping me refine my thoughts and approach challenges with clarity.  One of the most valuable things he shared  was, "You don’t have to be good at everything, but find your strength and focus on that." This simple yet profound advice changed how I approach my learning and career. He always reminded me the importance of documenting everything all my work, prioritizing my tasks, and understanding that IT is not a sprint, it’s a marathon. His words taught me patience, persistence, and the importance of structured learning.

What stood out most was his unwavering support. Whenever I struggled with a concept, he patiently explained it, often going the extra mile to recommend resources and break down complex topics. Even when he wasn’t familiar with a particular programming language, he still found ways to guide me, ensuring that I never felt stuck and this always left me feeling motivated and confident.  

His dedication was truly inspiring he never missed a single session, always showing up with enthusiasm and a genuine desire to help. His passion for mentorship and his commitment to seeing others succeed make him an exceptional person to learn from.  

I am deeply grateful to Groundbreaker for creating this mentorship program and for connecting me with such an outstanding mentor. And to Andreas, thank you for your patience, guidance, and unwavering support. Your impact goes beyond just technical knowledge, you’ve truly made a difference in my journey.

references.name: Edison de Azevedo Filho
references.reference: Andreas was the Product Owner and Architect for a project we worked on together. I had excellent experiences with Agile processes, and autonomy to manage activities, we experienced many processes running in Agile methodology. He provided an excellent working environment [...]. As an architect, he designed an architecture for a new system that was extremely modern, and despite the complexity of the project, he managed to make it easy to understand, as there was documentation of all points, in addition to constant architecture meetings with the team to discuss improvements.

references.name: Santana, Micael
references.reference: Andreas is a true asset to any team. He brings a wealth of knowledge and expertise in cloud architecture, and is always eager to lend a hand and share his insights. Beyond his technical skills, Andreas has a deep commitment to collaboration and teamwork, making him an valuable partner in any project. He is also dedicated to staying current with the latest advancements and trends in his field, ensuring that he is always at the forefront of innovation. [...]

references.name: Anamaria Onaciu
references.reference:
During the time we worked together, I learned the following things from Andreas. Things that are very important for a good team leader and a "healthy" team : 
- he knows very well the technical aspects, and this is very useful for the team and for the project
- he doesn’t say YES to each request from the team. He analyses together with the team members the best solution for them and for the project.
- he has a lot of patience
- he has a respectful attitude towards all team members
- he creates a favourable climate for the team to develop professionally and not to be afraid to ask questions or to say, "I don't know".
- he blocks the pressure from the client and other aspects / discussions which are not productive and should not be felt / reach by the team.
- he asks the team to make some decisions
- he discusses the real things for improvement to retrospective in a professional way
- he always comes with things to be improved and this helps to grow up the team
